title-group.article-title: Going beyond GDP: An OECD Perspective

abstract.p: This paper presents some of the main features of recent OECD work on people's well-being and societies' progress. After discussing the main limitations of GDP as a measure of 'welfare', the paper presents the multidimensional framework and rationale underpinning the OECD Better Life Initiative, and describes how this framework aims to overcome the limitations of GDP. The paper also presents some of the evidence from the OECD 'Better Life Index', an interactive tool that allows citizens to compare countries according to their own views and preferences on the relative importance of the different aspects of human well-being.

p.mixed-citation: Nordhaus and Tobin, 1973; Sen, 1985 and 1998; OECD, 2008c; Fleurbaey, 2009; Stiglitz, Sen and Fitoussi, 2009.

The notion of 'framework', in this context, should not be understood as referring to the type of 'accounting framework' used for economic statistics, with a sequence of accounts linked to each other in a logical sequence and with entries all expressed through a common metric (money). It is used here rather as a graphical representation of the dimensions and items that should be taken into account for any comprehensive assessment of individual and societal well-being.

The OECD Better Life Initiative approaches sustainability through the capital approach and in particular defines sustainability in terms of the non-negative change of some key assets that generate well-being over time. These assets comprise types of capital that are traditionally well measured by official statistical systems - for example, physical and natural capital - but also types of capital that remain challenging to measure across countries, notably human and social capital. Given these gaps, the dashboard of OECD well-being indicators includes at the moment only a few indicators of economic and environmental sustainability (for example, intensity of use of forest resources, nitrogen surplus intensities and freshwater abstraction) that are not discussed in this paper. The OECD is currently carrying out various research projects to build additional indicators of sustainability.
Sen, 1985; Anand et al., 2009; Anand, Durand and Heckman, 2011.

Fleurbaey (2006) highlights that functionings are 'selected achievements' that matter from a normative point of view - for instance, achievements that go beyond subjective well-being and encompass objective achievements. Functionings matter beyond resources, as people may have different attributes and needs, and can achieve different levels of well-being with the same amount of resources. Capabilities need to be considered alongside achievements to take into account the importance of freedom for human life (i.e. the possibility of choosing one's own functionings).
See, for example, Stiglitz, Sen and Fitoussi (2009) for a review, Sen (1998) and Nussbaum (2011).

Face validity is the capacity to capture what is intended to be measured. By summary outcomes, we refer to relatively broad achievements (for example, good health status) that can be easily understood and that display no ambiguity in interpretation, showing either good/bad performance or progress/regress when looking at changes over time.

For example, the indicator of household wealth currently included in the OECD set measures 'net financial wealth', i.e. the sum of financial assets and liabilities owned by households. Thus the indicator is only a limited proxy of people's consumption possibilities, as it excludes those non-financial assets (such as dwellings and land) that represent the bulk of household wealth in most countries because information on these currently does not exist on a comparable basis across OECD countries.

The SNA defines the general production boundary as referring to 'activity carried out under the control and responsibility of an institutional unit that uses inputs of labour, capital, and goods and services to produce outputs of goods and services' (SNA 2008, 6.24). The more restricted production boundary used in the SNA, however, excludes all household production of services for own final use, except services from owner-occupied dwellings and services produced by employing paid domestic staff (SNA 2008, 6.26).
Boarini, Johansson and Mira d'Ercole, 2006; Stiglitz, Sen and Fitoussi, 2009; Eurostat, 2011.

In principle, monetary evaluation of these non-market services could either rely on quality-adjusted market price equivalents of these non-market services (Holloway, Short and Tamplin, 2002) or, alternatively, be based on an estimation of the labour costs involved in producing these non-market services. In practice, the former method requires a large range of assumptions and various data that are not easily available, especially for cross-country comparisons. Therefore, most approaches in this field (as reflected in estimates of household satellite accounts) make use of the labour cost method.

The analysis summarised in Table 1 covers 34 OECD countries and six emerging economies (Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, Russian Federation and South Africa). The sample size in the Gallup World Poll is about 1,000 observations per country, with larger samples (around 4,000 observations) in some of the larger countries (such as China and India). The number of observations included in each regression is given in the table. These regressions are weighted with post-stratification weights provided by Gallup. Post-stratification weights correct for non-random response patterns to the survey. More information on these weights and the survey is available at https://worldview.gallup.com/content/methodology.asDx.

However, people with higher education do not report higher satisfaction with the quality of the local environment where they live. This can be explained by the higher environmental awareness and concerns of high-educated people (OECD, 201 la).
For a review, see Decancq and Lugo (2012), Sharpe (2011); Ravallion (2011), OECD (2008b).

In the OECD application, users are prompted to rate dimensions on a scale from 0 ('the item is not important at all') to 6 ('the item is extremely important'). These rates are then converted into relative weights by dividing them by the total sum of rates attributed by users to all dimensions. For the sake of simplicity and user-friendliness, users are asked to rate the 11 dimensions that make up well-being as if they were independent dimensions of well-being, i.e. at no point are users prompted to take into account interrelationships between the dimensions.

Weights applied to elementary indicators to obtain normalised scores by dimensions are set, for the sake of simplicity, in a normative way. Ideally, one would like to ask users to rate indicators directly. This would, however, be very difficult to visualise with a user-friendly tool. It should also be noted that, since the OECD well-being indicators are not available at the level of the individual (as emphasised in Section II), the BLI cannot be built as a true synthetic index, where well-being scores would be aggregated across dimensions and individuals. The BLI is obtained simply as a weighted average of a country's scores in the 11 dimensions, with weights assigned by users. Since 2012, the BLI has also been broken down for women and men (i.e. it corresponds to the weighted women/men country-average well-being scores of the 11 dimensions).
